item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Scientists were "...deeply concerned for the reputation of scientific investigation in their field."Sorry, but that's backwards. They should be concerned about the quality of the research in their field. It reminds me of the obsession with "confidence in the markets" at the expense of the economic fundamentals.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: The quote below is a case of shooting the messenger.What's not fair is that journals and institutions did not get their act together much sooner.Moreover, all the commentary that's been made public has been quite careful about not jumping to conclusions. The problem is just that some of the issues are self-evidently terrible: no right-minded scientist can unsee the issue or conceive of an innocent explanation...And, of course, the initial manipulations were also unfair.

item.description: I should add that I expect some coworkers to be genuinely blameless. item.title: Tarnport
item.description: Anders Zorn. Summer Pleasure, 1886.I share what art has been on my mind on a given day, but sometimes I hesitate over really famous works, like this one. This was the most expensive Swedish #painting ever to sell, and is likely the most famous artwork in that country. We might have seen the image enough times to feel wearied of it. But do you know what I think is the most amazing part? As if it weren't already mindblowing enough, it's a watercolor. It seems impossible. My jaw just slacks.

item.title: Richard Van Noorden
item.description:
Which scientific publishers/journals are worst affected by fraudulent or dubious research papers, and which have done least to clean up their portfolio?
A science-integrity startup called Argos says it has answers.
There are quite a few integrity tools now that look for red flags in papers, but this is the first to go public with what it's finding across journals and publishers.
Here's my exclusive look at their figures.
https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-024-03427-w
